reference.title: Types of Paper You Should and Should Not Use In A Manual Typewriter
reference.shortdesc: There are many types of paper with various uses. It is important to know what is appropriate to use in a typewriter, and what should be avoided.

dlentry.dd: 20 lb bond paper, feeds easily, rarely jams, absorbs ink, works best with a backing sheet.
24-28 lb bond paper, resists ink bleed-through. Typically used for letterhead, stationery, and manuscripts.
Papers such as vellum, linen, kraft, and embossed, typically used for crafting and elaborate stationery. They hold ink well, and are thick enough to not require a backing sheet.
25%-100% cotton paper, more durable than typical paper materials, typewriter printing is most crisp on cotton materials.
A protective sheet, made of thick paper, placed behind the typing paper in order to protect the rubber platen roller.
Printing on carbon paper required 3 to 4 sheets of paper to be inserted at once, which often leads to jamming or will excessively stress the typewriter platen.
Papers with additional coatings to increase smoothness or weight should be avoided as they do not absorb ink well and can lead to smudging.
Glossed paper may have difficulty being grabbed by the platen and feed rollers, and will not absorb ink well, leading to smudging.
